title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: vignette catalogs common join problems shows joinspy detects resolves . issue includes detection methods recommended solutions.

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: one tables duplicate keys, joins multiply rows unexpectedly. Detection: join_spy() reports duplicate counts expected row multiplication. Solution: Aggregate filter duplicates joining.
code: orders <- data.frame(   customer_id = c(1, 2, 2, 3),   amount = c(100, 50, 75, 200) )  addresses <- data.frame(   customer_id = c(1, 2, 2, 3),   address = c("NYC", "LA", "SF", "Chicago") )  join_spy(orders, addresses, by = "customer_id") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: customer_id #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 4 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 1 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 4 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 1 NA keys: 0 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 3 #> Keys only in left: 0 #> Keys only in right: 0 #> Match rate (left): "100%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! Left table has 1 duplicate key(s) affecting 2 rows - may cause row multiplication #> ! Right table has 1 duplicate key(s) affecting 2 rows - may cause row multiplication #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 6 #> left_join: 6 #> right_join: 6 #> full_join: 6 key_duplicates(orders, by = "customer_id") #>   customer_id amount .n_duplicates #> 2           2     50             2 #> 3           2     75             2 key_duplicates(addresses, by = "customer_id") #>   customer_id address .n_duplicates #> 2           2      LA             2 #> 3           2      SF             2

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: Invisible leading/trailing spaces prevent matches. Detection: join_spy() flags whitespace issues Issues section. Solution: Use join_repair() trimws().
code: sales <- data.frame(   product = c("Widget", "Gadget ", " Gizmo"),   units = c(10, 20, 30),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  inventory <- data.frame(   product = c("Widget", "Gadget", "Gizmo"),   stock = c(100, 200, 300),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  join_spy(sales, inventory, by = "product") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: product #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 1 #> Keys only in left: 2 #> Keys only in right: 2 #> Match rate (left): "33.3%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! Left column 'product' has 2 value(s) with leading/trailing whitespace #> ℹ 2 near-match(es) found (e.g., 'Gadget ' ~ 'Gadget', ' Gizmo' ~ 'Gizmo') - possible typos? #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 1 #> left_join: 3 #> right_join: 3 #> full_join: 5 sales_fixed <- join_repair(sales, by = "product") #> ✔ Repaired 2 value(s) key_check(sales_fixed, inventory, by = "product") #> ✔ Key check passed: no issues detected

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: Keys differ case (“ABC” vs “abc”). Detection: join_spy() detects case mismatches keys match case-insensitive. Solution: Standardize case join_repair().
code: left <- data.frame(   code = c("ABC", "def", "GHI"),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  right <- data.frame(   code = c("abc", "DEF", "ghi"),   label = c("A", "D", "G"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  join_spy(left, right, by = "code") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: code #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 0 #> Keys only in left: 3 #> Keys only in right: 3 #> Match rate (left): "0%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! 3 key(s) would match if case-insensitive (e.g., 'ABC' vs 'abc') #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 0 #> left_join: 3 #> right_join: 3 #> full_join: 6 repaired <- join_repair(left, right, by = "code", standardize_case = "upper") #> ✔ Repaired 3 value(s) key_check(repaired$x, repaired$y, by = "code") #> ✔ Key check passed: no issues detected

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: NA values key columns never match (design R). Detection: join_spy() reports NA counts Table Summary. Solution: Handle NA values explicitly—remove replace placeholder.
code: orders <- data.frame(   customer_id = c(1, NA, 3, NA),   amount = c(100, 200, 300, 400) )  customers <- data.frame(   customer_id = c(1, 2, 3, NA),   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Unknown") )  join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: customer_id #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 4 Unique keys: 2 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 2 #> Right table: Rows: 4 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 1 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 2 #> Keys only in left: 0 #> Keys only in right: 1 #> Match rate (left): "100%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! Left table has 2 NA key(s) - these will not match #> ! Right table has 1 NA key(s) - these will not match #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 2 #> left_join: 4 #> right_join: 4 #> full_join: 6 # Option 1: Remove rows with NA keys orders_clean <- orders[!is.na(orders$customer_id), ]  # Option 2: Replace NA with placeholder orders$customer_id[is.na(orders$customer_id)] <- -999

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: Inner join returns zero rows expected matches. Detection: Match analysis shows 0% match rate. Solution: Create mapping table transform keys common format.
code: system_a <- data.frame(   user_id = c("USR001", "USR002", "USR003"),   score = c(85, 90, 78),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  system_b <- data.frame(   user_id = c("1", "2", "3"),   department = c("Sales", "Marketing", "Engineering"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  report <- join_spy(system_a, system_b, by = "user_id") # Extract numeric part system_a$user_num <- gsub("USR0*", "", system_a$user_id) key_check(system_a, system_b, by = c("user_num" = "user_id")) #> ✔ Key check passed: no issues detected

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: tables duplicate keys, causing exponential row growth. Detection: Expected row counts show multiplication (inner join = 10 rows 9 source rows). Solution: Aggregate one table first, use check_cartesian().
code: order_items <- data.frame(   order_id = c(1, 1, 2, 2, 2),   item = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E") )  order_payments <- data.frame(   order_id = c(1, 1, 2, 2),   payment = c("CC1", "CC2", "Cash", "Check") )  report <- join_spy(order_items, order_payments, by = "order_id") check_cartesian(order_items, order_payments, by = "order_id") #> ✔ No Cartesian product risk (expansion factor: 2x) # Enforce cardinality to catch this join_strict(order_items, order_payments, by = "order_id", expect = "1:m") #> Error: #> ! Cardinality violation: expected 1:m but found m:m #>   Left duplicates: 2, Right duplicates: 2

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: Keys different types (numeric vs character). Detection: join_spy() flags type coercion warnings. Solution: Convert matching types joining.
code: orders <- data.frame(   product_id = c(1, 2, 3),   quantity = c(10, 20, 30) )  products <- data.frame(   product_id = c("1", "2", "3"),   name = c("Widget", "Gadget", "Gizmo"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  join_spy(orders, products, by = "product_id") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: product_id #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 3 #> Keys only in left: 0 #> Keys only in right: 0 #> Match rate (left): "100%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! Type mismatch: 'product_id' is numeric, 'product_id' is character - may cause unexpected results #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 3 #> left_join: 3 #> right_join: 3 #> full_join: 3 orders$product_id <- as.character(orders$product_id) key_check(orders, products, by = "product_id") #> ✔ Key check passed: no issues detected

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Problem: Empty strings ("") NA behave differently joins. Detection: join_spy() warns empty strings keys. Solution: Convert empty strings NA join_repair().
code: left <- data.frame(   id = c("A", "", "C"),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  right <- data.frame(   id = c("A", "B", ""),   label = c("Alpha", "Beta", "Empty"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  join_spy(left, right, by = "id") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: id #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 3 Unique keys: 3 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 2 #> Keys only in left: 1 #> Keys only in right: 1 #> Match rate (left): "66.7%" #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ℹ Left column 'id' has 1 empty string(s) - these match other empty strings but not NA #> ℹ Right column 'id' has 1 empty string(s) - these match other empty strings but not NA #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: NA #> left_join: NA #> right_join: NA #> full_join: NA left_fixed <- join_repair(left, by = "id", empty_to_na = TRUE) #> ✔ Repaired 1 value(s) left_fixed$id #> [1] "A" NA  "C"

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: know expected cardinality, use join_strict() fail fast:
code: products <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("A", "B", "C")) prices <- data.frame(id = c(1, 2, 2, 3), price = c(10, 20, 25, 30))  join_strict(products, prices, by = "id", expect = "1:1") #> Error: #> ! Cardinality violation: expected 1:1 but found 1:m #>   Left duplicates: 0, Right duplicates: 1

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Let joinspy determine actual relationship:
code: orders <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3), item = c("A", "B", "C", "D")) customers <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol"))  detect_cardinality(orders, customers, by = "id") #> ℹ Detected cardinality: "m:1" #> Left duplicates: 1 key(s)

title: Common Join Issues and Solutions
text: Run join_spy(x, y, ) get comprehensive diagnostic Check Issues section detected problems Use key_duplicates() locate specific duplicate rows Apply join_repair() fix whitespace/case/encoding issues Use join_strict() enforce expected cardinality joining, use join_explain() understand row count changes

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: joinspy provides diagnostic tools understanding debugging data frame joins R. Instead discovering join problems fact, joinspy helps identify issues upfront understand happen join. Key features: Pre-join diagnostics join_spy() key_check() Duplicate detection key_duplicates() Post-join analysis join_explain() join_diff() Safe wrappers: left_join_spy(), right_join_spy(), inner_join_spy(), full_join_spy() Cardinality enforcement join_strict() Auto-repair join_repair() suggest_repairs() Visualization plot() summary() methods

title: Getting Started with joinspy
code: # Install development version from GitHub # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("gcol33/joinspy")

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: joinspy analyzes join keys join, detecting: Duplicate keys (causes row multiplication) Whitespace issues (leading/trailing spaces) Case mismatches (“ABC” vs “abc”) Encoding problems (invisible Unicode characters) NA values keys Type mismatches (numeric vs character)

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Use summary() compact data frame metrics:
code: # Sample data with issues orders <- data.frame(    customer_id = c("A", "B", "B", "C", "D "),   amount = c(100, 200, 150, 300, 50),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  customers <- data.frame(   customer_id = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "David", "Eve"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Get diagnostic report report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id") summary(report) #>               metric value #> 1          left_rows  5.00 #> 2         right_rows  5.00 #> 3   left_unique_keys  4.00 #> 4  right_unique_keys  5.00 #> 5       keys_matched  3.00 #> 6     keys_left_only  1.00 #> 7    keys_right_only  2.00 #> 8         match_rate  0.75 #> 9             issues  2.00 #> 10   inner_join_rows  4.00 #> 11    left_join_rows  5.00 #> 12   right_join_rows  6.00 #> 13    full_join_rows  7.00

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: fast pass/fail assessment:
code: key_check(orders, customers, by = "customer_id") #> ! Key check found 2 issue(s): #> ✖ Left table has 1 duplicate key(s) (2 rows affected) #> ✖ Left table column 'customer_id' has whitespace issues (1 values)

title: Getting Started with joinspy
code: key_duplicates(orders, by = "customer_id") #>   customer_id amount .n_duplicates #> 2           B    200             2 #> 3           B    150             2

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Use *_join_spy() functions joins automatic diagnostics: Available wrappers:
code: orders_clean <- data.frame(   customer_id = c("A", "B", "C"),   amount = c(100, 200, 300),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Silent mode for pipelines result <- left_join_spy(orders_clean, customers, by = "customer_id", .quiet = TRUE) head(result) #>   customer_id amount  name #> 1           A    100 Alice #> 2           B    200   Bob #> 3           C    300 Carol  # Access diagnostics afterward last_report()$match_analysis$match_rate #> [1] 1

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Use join_strict() enforce expected relationships:
code: products <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("Widget", "Gadget", "Gizmo")) prices <- data.frame(id = 1:3, price = c(10, 20, 30))  # Succeeds - 1:1 relationship join_strict(products, prices, by = "id", expect = "1:1") #>   id   name price #> 1  1 Widget    10 #> 2  2 Gadget    20 #> 3  3  Gizmo    30 # Fails - duplicates violate 1:1 prices_dup <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3), price = c(10, 15, 20, 30)) join_strict(products, prices_dup, by = "id", expect = "1:1") #> Error: #> ! Cardinality violation: expected 1:1 but found 1:m #>   Left duplicates: 0, Right duplicates: 1

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Fix common issues automatically:
code: messy <- data.frame(   id = c(" A", "B ", "  C  "),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Preview repairs join_repair(messy, by = "id", dry_run = TRUE) #>  #> ── Repair Preview (Dry Run) ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Left table (x) ── #>  #> ℹ id: trimmed whitespace (3)  # Apply repairs fixed <- join_repair(messy, by = "id") #> ✔ Repaired 3 value(s) fixed$id #> [1] "A" "B" "C"

title: Getting Started with joinspy
code: orders_dup <- data.frame(id = 1:3, product = c("A", "B", "C")) inventory <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3), location = c("NY", "LA", "NY", "LA"))  result <- merge(orders_dup, inventory, by = "id") join_explain(result, orders_dup, inventory, by = "id", type = "inner") #>  #> ── Join Explanation ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Row Counts ── #>  #> Left table (x): 3 rows #> Right table (y): 4 rows #> Result: 4 rows #> ! Result has 1 more rows than left table #>  #> ── Why the row count changed ── #>  #> ℹ Right table has 1 duplicate key(s) - each match creates multiple rows

title: Getting Started with joinspy
code: before <- data.frame(id = 1:3, val = c("a", "b", "c")) after <- merge(before, data.frame(id = 2:4, name = c("B", "C", "D")), by = "id", all = TRUE)  join_diff(before, after, by = "id") #>  #> ── Join Diff ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Dimensions ── #>  #> Before: 3 rows x 2 columns #> After: 4 rows x 3 columns #> Change: "+1" rows, "+1" columns #>  #> ── Column Changes ── #>  #> ✔ Added: name #>  #> ── Key Analysis ── #>  #> Unique keys before: 3 #> Unique keys after: 4

title: Getting Started with joinspy
code: orders <- data.frame(id = 1:5, val = 1:5) customers <- data.frame(id = 3:7, name = letters[3:7])  report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "id") plot(report)  # Venn diagram

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Comprehensive pre-join diagnostic report. Returns: JoinReport S3 object print(), summary(), plot() methods.
code: join_spy(x, y, by, sample = NULL, ...)

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Quick pass/fail key quality assessment. Returns: Logical TRUE keys clean, FALSE otherwise (messages).
code: key_check(x, y, by)

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Join cardinality enforcement. Returns: Joined data frame, error cardinality violated.
code: join_strict(x, y, by, type = "left", expect = "1:1")

title: Getting Started with joinspy
text: Automatically fix common key issues. Returns: Repaired data frame(s).
code: join_repair(x, y = NULL, by, trim_whitespace = TRUE,             standardize_case = NULL, remove_invisible = TRUE,             empty_to_na = FALSE, dry_run = FALSE)

text: Fix common issues automatically:
code: messy <- data.frame(   id = c(" A", "B ", "  C  "),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Preview repairs join_repair(messy, by = "id", dry_run = TRUE) #>  #> ── Repair Preview (Dry Run) ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Left table (x) ── #>  #> ℹ id: trimmed whitespace (3)  # Apply repairs fixed <- join_repair(messy, by = "id") #> ✔ Repaired 3 value(s) fixed$id #> [1] "A" "B" "C"

title: Quick Start
code: orders_dup <- data.frame(id = 1:3, product = c("A", "B", "C")) inventory <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3), location = c("NY", "LA", "NY", "LA"))  result <- merge(orders_dup, inventory, by = "id") join_explain(result, orders_dup, inventory, by = "id", type = "inner") #>  #> ── Join Explanation ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Row Counts ── #>  #> Left table (x): 3 rows #> Right table (y): 4 rows #> Result: 4 rows #> ! Result has 1 more rows than left table #>  #> ── Why the row count changed ── #>  #> ℹ Right table has 1 duplicate key(s) - each match creates multiple rows

title: Quick Start
code: before <- data.frame(id = 1:3, val = c("a", "b", "c")) after <- merge(before, data.frame(id = 2:4, name = c("B", "C", "D")), by = "id", all = TRUE)  join_diff(before, after, by = "id") #>  #> ── Join Diff ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Dimensions ── #>  #> Before: 3 rows x 2 columns #> After: 4 rows x 3 columns #> Change: "+1" rows, "+1" columns #>  #> ── Column Changes ── #>  #> ✔ Added: name #>  #> ── Key Analysis ── #>  #> Unique keys before: 3 #> Unique keys after: 4

title: Quick Start
code: orders <- data.frame(id = 1:5, val = 1:5) customers <- data.frame(id = 3:7, name = letters[3:7])  report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "id") plot(report)  # Venn diagram

title: CLAUDE.md
text: joinspy R package provides diagnostic tools data frame joins. helps users understand debug join operations analyzing key columns joins, detecting common issues (duplicates, mismatches, encoding problems), explaining unexpected row count changes.

title: CLAUDE.md

title: CLAUDE.md

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Build vignettes devtools::build_vignettes()  # Build pkgdown site locally (output in docs/) pkgdown::build_site()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package provides diagnostic functions organized three categories: join_spy() - Comprehensive pre-flight report key_check() - Quick key quality assessment key_duplicates() - Find duplicate keys join_explain() - Explain row count changes join_diff() - Compare /states left_join_spy() - left_join automatic reporting join_strict() - Fails cardinality constraints violated

title: CLAUDE.md
text: JoinReport S3 class - Returned join_spy() related functions: - x_summary - Summary left table keys - y_summary - Summary right table keys - match_analysis - /won’t match - issues - Detected problems (duplicates, whitespace, encoding, case) - expected_rows - Predicted row counts join type

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package detects common issues: 1. Duplicate keys - Keys appearing multiple times (causes row multiplication) 2. Trailing/leading whitespace - Invisible characters breaking matches 3. Case mismatches - “ABC” vs “abc” won’t match 4. Encoding issues - UTF-8 vs Latin-1, invisible Unicode characters 5. NA keys - Missing values join columns

title: CLAUDE.md
code: R/                           # R source files ├── join_spy.R              # Main diagnostic function ├── key_check.R             # Key quality assessment ├── key_duplicates.R        # Duplicate detection ├── join_explain.R          # Post-join explanation ├── join_diff.R             # Before/after comparison ├── join_strict.R           # Cardinality-enforcing joins ├── join_wrappers.R         # *_join_spy() convenience functions ├── JoinReport.R            # S3 class definition and print method ├── string_diagnostics.R    # Encoding/whitespace detection utilities └── joinspy-package.R       # Package-level documentation  tests/testthat/             # Unit tests ├── test-join_spy.R ├── test-key_check.R ├── test-join_explain.R ├── test-join_strict.R └── test-string_diagnostics.R  vignettes/                   # Long-form documentation ├── introduction.Rmd        # Getting started guide └── common-issues.Rmd       # Catalogue of join problems and solutions  man/                         # Generated documentation (roxygen2) docs/                        # Generated pkgdown website

what: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
text: Diagnostic Tools Data Frame Joins R joinspy package helps understand debug join operations analyzing key columns joins, detecting common issues, explaining unexpected row count changes. Catch problems early instead discovering downstream analysis breaks.

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
code: library(joinspy)  # Pre-join diagnostics report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id") summary(report)  # Quick pass/fail check key_check(orders, customers, by = "customer_id")  # Safe join with cardinality enforcement result <- join_strict(orders, customers, by = "customer_id", expect = "1:1")  # Auto-repair common issues orders_fixed <- join_repair(orders, by = "customer_id")

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
text: Joins silently produce unexpected results : Duplicate keys cause row multiplication Trailing whitespace breaks matches invisibly Case mismatches (“ABC” vs “abc”) prevent joins Encoding issues make identical-looking strings different NA values keys cause unexpected behavior Type mismatches (character “1” vs numeric 1) fail silently problems discovered downstream analysis breaks. joinspy catches upfront analyzing keys join, explaining joins misbehave, showing problems .

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins

text: join_strict(): Join cardinality enforcement (1:1, 1:m, m:1, m:m) left_join_spy(), right_join_spy(), inner_join_spy(), full_join_spy(): Joins automatic diagnostics last_report(): Retrieve diagnostics silent (.quiet = TRUE) joins

text: join_repair(): Fix whitespace, case, encoding, empty strings automatically suggest_repairs(): Generate R code snippets fix detected issues

text: plot(): Venn diagram key overlap (optional file param save) summary(): Compact metrics table (optional format param text/markdown) log_report(): Write reports file (text/JSON/RDS) set_log_file(): Enable automatic logging

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
code: library(joinspy)  orders <- data.frame(   customer_id = c("A", "B", "B", "C", "D "),   amount = c(100, 200, 150, 300, 50),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  customers <- data.frame(   customer_id = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "David", "Eve"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Full diagnostic report report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id")  # Compact summary summary(report) #>              metric value #> 1         left_rows     5 #> 2        right_rows     5 #> 3   left_unique_keys    4 #> 4  right_unique_keys    5 #> ...

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
code: # Succeeds - 1:1 relationship products <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("Widget", "Gadget", "Gizmo")) prices <- data.frame(id = 1:3, price = c(10, 20, 30))  join_strict(products, prices, by = "id", expect = "1:1")  # Fails - duplicates violate 1:1 prices_dup <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3), price = c(10, 15, 20, 30)) join_strict(products, prices_dup, by = "id", expect = "1:1") #> Error: Cardinality violation: expected '1:1' but found '1:m'

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
code: messy <- data.frame(   id = c(" A", "B ", "  C  "),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Preview what would be fixed join_repair(messy, by = "id", dry_run = TRUE)  # Apply fixes fixed <- join_repair(messy, by = "id") fixed$id #> [1] "A" "B" "C"

title: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins
code: # Silent join for pipelines result <- left_join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id", .quiet = TRUE)  # Access diagnostics afterward last_report()$match_analysis$match_rate #> [1] 0.8

code: report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id")  # Venn diagram plot(report)  # Save to file plot(report, file = "overlap.png")

title: Analyze Multi-Table Join Chain — analyze_join_chain
text: summary join chain analysis.

title: Analyze Multi-Table Join Chain — analyze_join_chain
code: orders <- data.frame(order_id = 1:3, customer_id = c(1, 2, 2)) customers <- data.frame(customer_id = 1:3, region_id = c(1, 1, 2)) regions <- data.frame(region_id = 1:2, name = c("North", "South"))  analyze_join_chain(   tables = list(orders = orders, customers = customers, regions = regions),   joins = list(     list(left = "orders", right = "customers", by = "customer_id"),     list(left = "result", right = "regions", by = "region_id")   ) ) #>  #> ── Join Chain Analysis ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Step 1: orders + customers ── #>  #> Left: 3 rows #> Right: 3 rows #> Match rate: 100% #> Expected result: 3 rows (left join) #> ! 1 issue(s) detected #>  #>  #> ── Step 2: result + regions ── #>  #> Left: 9 rows #> Right: 2 rows #> Match rate: 100% #> Expected result: 9 rows (left join) #> ! 1 issue(s) detected #>  #>  #> ── Chain Summary ── #>  #> ! Total issues across chain: 2

code: # Dangerous: both tables have duplicates x <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 2), val_x = 1:4) y <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 2), val_y = 1:4)  check_cartesian(x, y, by = "id") #> ✔ No Cartesian product risk (expansion factor: 2x)

what: joinspy: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins — joinspy-package
title: joinspy: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins — joinspy-package
text: Provides diagnostic tools understanding debugging data frame joins. Analyzes key columns joining detect duplicates, mismatches, encoding issues, common problems. Explains unexpected row count changes provides safe join wrappers cardinality enforcement. Concepts diagnostics build tidy data principles described 'Wickham' (2014) doi:10.18637/jss.v059.i10 .

title: joinspy: Diagnostic Tools for Data Frame Joins — joinspy-package
text: Maintainer: Gilles Colling gilles.colling051@gmail.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]

code: before <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = letters[1:3]) after <- data.frame(id = c(1, 2, 2, 3), x = c("a", "b", "b", "c"), y = 1:4 )  join_diff(before, after) #>  #> ── Join Diff ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Dimensions ── #>  #> Before: 3 rows x 2 columns #> After: 4 rows x 3 columns #> Change: "+1" rows, "+1" columns #>  #>  #> ── Column Changes ── #>  #> ✔ Added: y #>

what: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
title: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
text: performing join, use function understand row count changed. analyzes original tables result explain difference.

title: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
code: join_explain(result, x, y, by, type = NULL)

title: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
text: result result join operation. x original left data frame. y original right data frame. character vector column names used join. type Character. type join performed. One "left", "right", "inner", "full". NULL (default), attempts infer join type row counts.

title: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
text: Invisibly returns list explanation details. Prints human-readable explanation.

title: Explain Row Count Changes After a Join — join_explain
code: orders <- data.frame(id = c(1, 2, 2, 3), value = 1:4) customers <- data.frame(id = c(1, 2, 2, 4), name = c("A", "B1", "B2", "D"))  result <- merge(orders, customers, by = "id", all.x = TRUE)  # Explain why we got more rows than expected join_explain(result, orders, customers, by = "id", type = "left") #>  #> ── Join Explanation ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Row Counts ── #>  #> Left table (x): 4 rows #> Right table (y): 4 rows #> Result: 6 rows #> ! Result has 2 more rows than left table #>  #>  #> ── Why the row count changed ── #>  #> ℹ Both tables have duplicate keys - this causes multiplicative row expansion #> ℹ 1 left key(s) have no match in right table

title: Repair Common Key Issues — join_repair

title: Repair Common Key Issues — join_repair
code: join_repair(   x,   y = NULL,   by,   trim_whitespace = TRUE,   standardize_case = NULL,   remove_invisible = TRUE,   empty_to_na = FALSE,   dry_run = FALSE )

title: Repair Common Key Issues — join_repair
text: x data frame (left table). y data frame (right table). NULL, repairs x. character vector column names repair. trim_whitespace Logical. Trim leading/trailing whitespace. Default TRUE. standardize_case Character. Standardize case "lower", "upper", NULL (change). Default NULL. remove_invisible Logical. Remove invisible Unicode characters. Default TRUE. empty_to_na Logical. Convert empty strings NA. Default FALSE. dry_run Logical. TRUE, report changed without modifying data. Default FALSE.

title: Repair Common Key Issues — join_repair
text: y NULL, returns repaired x. provided, returns list x y. dry_run mode, returns summary proposed changes.

title: Repair Common Key Issues — join_repair
code: # Data with whitespace issues orders <- data.frame(   id = c(" A", "B ", "C"),   value = 1:3,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Dry run to see what would change join_repair(orders, by = "id", dry_run = TRUE) #>  #> ── Repair Preview (Dry Run) ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Left table (x) ── #>  #> ℹ id: trimmed whitespace (2)  # Actually repair orders_fixed <- join_repair(orders, by = "id") #> ✔ Repaired 2 value(s)

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
text: Analyzes two data frames joining detect potential issues predict outcome. Returns detailed report key quality, match rates, detected problems.

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
code: join_spy(x, y, by, sample = NULL, ...)

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
text: x data frame (left table join). y data frame (right table join). character vector column names join , named character vector joins column names differ (e.g., c("id" = "customer_id")). sample Integer NULL. provided, randomly sample many rows table faster diagnostics large datasets. Default NULL (analyze rows). ... Reserved future use.

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
text: JoinReport object following components: x_summary Summary statistics keys left table y_summary Summary statistics keys right table match_analysis Details keys /match issues List detected problems (duplicates, whitespace, etc.) expected_rows Predicted row counts join type

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
text: function detects following common join issues: Duplicate keys: Keys appearing multiple times, cause row multiplication joins Whitespace: Leading trailing spaces prevent matches Case mismatches: Keys differ case (e.g., "ABC" vs "abc") Encoding issues: Different character encodings invisible Unicode characters NA values: Missing values key columns

title: Comprehensive Pre-Join Diagnostic Report — join_spy
code: # Create sample data with issues orders <- data.frame(   order_id = 1:5,   customer_id = c("A", "B", "B", "C", "D ") ) customers <- data.frame(   customer_id = c("A", "B", "C", "E"),   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Eve") )  # Get diagnostic report join_spy(orders, customers, by = "customer_id") #>  #> ── Join Diagnostic Report ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Join columns: customer_id #>  #>  #> ── Table Summary ── #>  #> Left table: Rows: 5 Unique keys: 4 Duplicate keys: 1 NA keys: 0 #> Right table: Rows: 4 Unique keys: 4 Duplicate keys: 0 NA keys: 0 #>  #>  #> ── Match Analysis ── #>  #> Keys in both: 3 #> Keys only in left: 1 #> Keys only in right: 1 #> Match rate (left): "75%" #>  #>  #> ── Issues Detected ── #>  #> ! Left table has 1 duplicate key(s) affecting 2 rows - may cause row multiplication #> ! Left column 'customer_id' has 1 value(s) with leading/trailing whitespace #>  #>  #> ── Expected Row Counts ── #>  #> inner_join: 4 #> left_join: 5 #> right_join: 5 #> full_join: 6

what: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
title: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
text: Performs join operation fails specified cardinality constraint violated. Use catch unexpected many--many relationships early.

title: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
code: join_strict(   x,   y,   by,   type = c("left", "right", "inner", "full"),   expect = c("1:1", "1:m", "1:many", "m:1", "many:1", "m:m", "many:many"),   ... )

title: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
text: x data frame (left table). y data frame (right table). character vector column names join . type Character. type join perform. One "left" (default), "right", "inner", "full". expect Character. expected cardinality relationship. One : "1:1" key x matches one key y, vice versa "1:m" "1:many" key x can match multiple keys y, key y matches one key x "m:1" "many:1" key y can match multiple keys x, key x matches one key y "m:m" "many:many" cardinality constraints (allows relationships) ... Additional arguments passed underlying join function.

title: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
text: joined data frame cardinality constraint satisfied. Throws error constraint violated.

title: Strict Join with Cardinality Enforcement — join_strict
code: orders <- data.frame(id = 1:3, product = c("A", "B", "C")) customers <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol"))  # This succeeds (1:1 relationship) join_strict(orders, customers, by = "id", expect = "1:1") #>   id product  name #> 1  1       A Alice #> 2  2       B   Bob #> 3  3       C Carol  # This fails if customers had duplicate ids (wrapped in try to show error) customers_dup <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2), name = c("A1", "A2", "B")) try(join_strict(orders, customers_dup, by = "id", expect = "1:1")) #> Error : Cardinality violation: expected 1:1 but found 1:m #> 	 Left duplicates: 0, Right duplicates: 1

title: Summary Method for JoinReport — summary.JoinReport
code: orders <- data.frame(id = 1:5, val = 1:5) customers <- data.frame(id = 3:7, name = letters[3:7])  report <- join_spy(orders, customers, by = "id") summary(report) #>               metric value #> 1          left_rows   5.0 #> 2         right_rows   5.0 #> 3   left_unique_keys   5.0 #> 4  right_unique_keys   5.0 #> 5       keys_matched   3.0 #> 6     keys_left_only   2.0 #> 7    keys_right_only   2.0 #> 8         match_rate   0.6 #> 9             issues   0.0 #> 10   inner_join_rows   3.0 #> 11    left_join_rows   5.0 #> 12   right_join_rows   5.0 #> 13    full_join_rows   7.0 summary(report, format = "markdown") #> | Metric | Value | #> |--------|-------| #> | left_rows | 5 | #> | right_rows | 5 | #> | left_unique_keys | 5 | #> | right_unique_keys | 5 | #> | keys_matched | 3 | #> | keys_left_only | 2 | #> | keys_right_only | 2 | #> | match_rate | 0.6 | #> | issues | 0 | #> | inner_join_rows | 3 | #> | left_join_rows | 5 | #> | right_join_rows | 5 | #> | full_join_rows | 7 |
